stem: The nurse is reviewing the EHR for two clients on a medical unit. Based on the clinical data in the EHR, match each assessment finding to the appropriate fluid volume state.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient A: 62-year-old male with ESRD. He missed his last two dialysis appointments and presents with severe shortness of breath. Noted generalized edema. 
Patient B: 54-year-old female with a history of profuse diuretic abuse for weight loss. She was found in her home by a neighbor, appearing lethargic and confused.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content:
PatientBPHRWeight ChangeJVP
Patient A182/104110+5.4 kg (1 week)Distended (12 cm)
Patient B84/42132-4.1 kg (1 week)Flat supine

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
Patient A: Pitting edema 4+ to lower thighs. S3 gallop. Crackles throughout upper and lower lobes. 
Patient B: Mucous membranes dry and crusty. Skin turgor reveals tenting for 5 seconds. Eyes appear sunken.

rows.text: Hemodilution (Low Na+, Low Hct, Low Osmolality)
Hemoconcentration (High Na+, High Hct, High Osmolality)
Prominent distension of neck veins while sitting at 45 degrees
Hypotension, tachycardia, and flat neck veins
Presence of S3 gallop and crackles on auscultation

rationale.correct: FVE leads to hemodilution, where the extra water 'dilutes' the sodium and red blood cells (lowered Na+ and Hct). Physical signs include fluid overload in the heart (S3) and lungs (crackles). FVD leads to hemoconcentration, elevated osmolality, and orthostatic hypotension from a lack of intravascular volume.
clinicalPearls: Concentrated labs (High Hct, Sp. Gravity, Na+) = Dry Patient.
Diluted labs (Low Hct, Na+) = Wet Patient.
In heart failure, the S3 is the sound of fluid volume overload 'crashing' into a full ventricle.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking that a High Sodium always means the patient ate 'too much salt'.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: In FVD, high sodium is often a reflection of 'too little water' rather than too much intake.

mnemonic.title: The Fluid Flow
mnemonic.expansion: FVD: Values go UP (Hct, Na, SG). FVE: Values go Down (Dilution).
